choices.D: The router sends only a label for the prefix for Loopback0.
choices.B: The router must have TDP configured for the send-label command to operate.
choices.C: The neighbor router receives at least four labels from this router.
choices.A: The router sends BGP labels for its prefixes to this peer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A: correct, it's configured with "send-label" to send labels for its prefixes to the peer
B: incorrect, you can use send-label with LDP or TDP
C: you have no way of knowing how many labels this router will be sending to the peer based on the information given. This router could be learning many prefixes from many BGP neighbors not shown
D: Lo0 is the source IP for this router to communicate from, and has nothing to do with advertising that interface's prefix... you don't even know if this router is advertising its Lo0 interface's prefix via BGP, it could be advertising Lo0's prefix via an IGP before it even tries to build BGP neighbors

Selected Answer: A
As someone else stated, we cannot be certain that the 192.168.1.2 address corresponds to Loopback 0, so D is uncertain and therefore A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
We do not specifically know if 192.168.1.2 is a prefix from Loopback0 (could be another interface as well). So I would go with A.

Selected Answer: A
I tested it in the lab and correct answer is “A”; all prefix learned by BGP will be advertised with a label to 192.168.1.1 peer.

Selected Answer: D
For BGP LU we need to tell which /32 networks will get advertised. No redistribution of connected command is seen too.

choices.C: BGP updates from the eBGP peers are appended with an additional AS path value that is statically set by the domain administrator.
choices.A: BGP updates from the iBGP peers are appended with a community of local-as.
choices.D: BGP updates from the eBGP peers are appended with a BGPsec attribute sequence that includes a public key hash and digital signature.
choices.B: BGP updates from the all BGP peers are appended with a community of no-export.

discussion.content: D is more correct than A.
Answer D is more specific so thats the better answer indeed. Like a more specific route has priority over a less specific route ;-)

Selected Answer: D
R1 is a L2 router ("area router")
R2 is a L1 router ("station router")
They will not form an adjacency (although if either of them were configured as L1/L2, which is the default, they could)

The NET (in Cisco's format) is formed by three parts:
- the area-id (single octet plus two additional bytes)
- the system-id (six octets)
- the SEL

Systems with same area-id can become L1 neighbors.
Systems with different area-ids can become L2 neighbors.


The NET for R1 is: 52.0011.0000.0000.0001.00
 - area-id 52.0011
 - system-id 0000.0000.0001
 - the SEL is 00

The NET for R2 is: 52.0022.0000.0000.0002.00
 - area-id 52.0022
 - system-id 0000.0000.0002
 - the SEL is 00
 
Therefore R1 and R2 are in different areas.
R2 is an L1 router, and thus cannot form an adjacency with R1 in a different area.

So there are two reasons why they cannot form an adjacency.

Answer: D

Selected Answer: D
As someone else stated, in IS-IS there are no area "types", only levels. So D is more correct than A.
A says "configured with different area types", L1 and L2 are not area types, they are router levels.

Selected Answer: D
A is not correct because even if you configure both routers to be L1 they will still not for neighborship due to different area

Selected Answer: A
Sorry guys, I believe I was wrong with D:

A is correct. If you change the area type on R2 to level-2 it will work
D is wrong. Neighbor is not down because of the area ID, changing the area ID will not fix this if you leave the area type as level-1

D is not my favorite answer , even if you match the area, ISIS nbr wont come up as R1 is Level 1 only router and R2 is Level 2 only router, as per below documentation L1 and L2 only device will not form any ardency 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/integrated-intermediate-system-to-intermediate-system-is-is/200293-IS-IS-Adjacency-and-Area-Types.html#anc5 
(check the IS-IS Adjacency Table)

so A looks a better ans if "area type" is referring to "is-tyoe"

comments.content:
R1 - level-2
R2 - level-1

Only way to form neighbor is if that are in the same area (level-1) as they can only form level-1 peering.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
An L1 adjacency is formed only with routers in the same area.
An L2 adjacency is formed with routers in the same area or a different area.
An ISIS router will form L1 and L2 adjacencies by default with a router in the same area.
We see that:
Router 1 is level-2 area 52.0011
Router 2 is level-1 area 52.0022

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct Answer

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Read carefully https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/integrated-intermediate-system-to-intermediate-system-is-is/200293-IS-IS-Adjacency-and-Area-Types.html
A is more correct, if we have two routers configured as L2, the area id dont matter.

For the answer A, we have 3 cases when they have same area type:
1. both are in area type 1 -> it will not work because different area (0011 vs 0022)
2. both are in area type 2 -> it will work because area difference does not matter
3. both are in area type1-2 -> it will work because area difference does not matter
So the logic tells us that case 1 will invalidate this answer.
The remaining vaild answer is D
D is correct. It doesn't even matter the area, as the routers will send different different hello messages (L1 and L2 hellos) and they will not form an adjacency.

D is not MORE correct than A... it's the only correct answer. It's not more specific it's not more anything... A is WRONG!!! Before you spew useless information using the Cisco documentation why don't you actually demonstrate the nonesense you are passing on.... Try in the lab and tell me I'm wrong... I dare you.

discussion.content: A is correct. Fight me!
D is correct. They are in different area, but because Router2 is L1 only, it cannot form an adjacency with other routers that are in different area. Only L2 routers can do that.

In my opinion correct answer is D 100%. 
In A:
The neighbor relationship is down because the two routers are configured with different area types. - Routers are configured with different area types can have a relationship if they are in Level-2 or Level-1-2 routers. It doesn't mention something about routers' types.
But in D:
The neighbor relationship is down because R2 is operating as a Level 1 router and the two routers are in different areas. - It is obviously mentioned that, Router2 is Level-1 router and it should be on the same area with its neighbor.
In answer A they're talking about area types. According to me there's no such thing. Router types or area id's but not area types.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2294214

comments.content:
MTU
The IP MTU parameter determines the maximum size of an IPv4 packet that can be forwarded out the interface without fragmentation. If a packet with an IPv4 MTU larger than the maximum arrives at the router interface, it will be either discarded, if the DF bit in the packet header is set, or it will be fragmented. OSPF for IPv4 packets completely relies on IPv4 for the possible fragmentation. Although RFC 2328 does not recommend OSPF packet fragmentation, in some situations the size of the OSPF packet has greater value than the interface IPv4 MTU. If MTUs are mismatched between two neighbors, this could introduce issues with exchange of link-state packets, resulting in continuous retransmissions.

NOTE

The interface command for setting the IPv6 MTU parameter is ipv6 mtu. An IPv6 router does not fragment an IPv6 packet unless it is the source of the packet.

To prevent such issues, OSPF requires that the same IPv4 MTU be configured on both sides of the link. If neighbors have a mismatched IPv4 MTU configured, they will not be able to form full OSPF adjacency. They will be stuck in the ExStart adjacency state.

discussion.content:
Forming an OSPF adjacency requires that the following parameters match on OSPF-enabled interfaces:
 Hello and dead timers
 Network mask (for broadcast network types only)
 Need for a DR
 +++Matching MTU (unless configured to ignore MTU)+++
 Unique RIDs
 Interfaces sharing a common subnet with matching OSPF area ID
 Authentication type and credentials
 Area flags
wouldn't duplex/half duplex be an issue?

comments.content: For sure, far from ideal. But adjaceny might actually come up whereas MTU will prevent.

discussion.content:
@Onny and @ zayd_dean, even if MTU is not mentioned compulsory matching conditions, we need it to be matched. Otherwise, routers will be stuck in EXSTART state.
The answer is "D. mtu" for sure.

@zyad_dean
Technically MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) is not a part of compulsory matching conditions. Still we should match this value. If this value does not match routers may stuck in Exstart/Exchange exchange stage.

Correct answer is MTU but find it odd it is never listed as one of the parameters for OSPF adjacencies.
